intro: Galium serratohamatum, commonly known as the serrated wood sorrel, is a flowering plant belonging to the Rubiaceae family. It is characterized by its creeping growth habit and trifoliate leaves with serrated edges. The plant produces small, white or pale yellow flowers arranged in clusters, typically blooming in late spring to early summer. Native to the southeastern United States, it thrives in moist, shaded environments such as woodlands and stream banks. Its botanical features make it a distinctive and ecologically important species in its native habitat.
